statusModel.ELIGIBLE: Meets eligibility; next dose not due within dueSoonWindowDays.
statusModel.DUE_SOON: Next scheduled dose is within dueSoonWindowDays.
statusModel.OVERDUE: Next scheduled dose date is in the past.

reasons: COVID-19 eligibility changes over time; this clause assumes your app sets COVID_ELIGIBLE_NOW when current Manitoba criteria are met.

vaccineRules.notes: Placeholder: Manitoba’s vaccine eligibility page links out for current COVID-19 criteria. Use a questionnaire or an admin toggle to set riskTag COVID_ELIGIBLE_NOW.

reasons: DTaP-IPV-Hib is publicly funded for children under 7 who are not fully immunized.
Specialist-directed schedules (e.g., CancerCare Manitoba / transplant) may require additional/redo doses in children under 7.
Hib is publicly funded for children under 5 who are not fully immunized.
Certain high-risk medical conditions or specialist programs may qualify for Hib vaccination beyond routine childhood schedules.
Hepatitis A outbreak eligibility includes specified communities (e.g., Island Lake area, Peguis First Nation) and people travelling to/working in those communities.
Hepatitis A vaccine is publicly funded for contacts of cases or common exposures during outbreaks.
Manitoba school-based hepatitis B program: eligible cohort (use GRADE6_PROGRAM/HBV_SCHOOL_PROGRAM to confirm).
Catch-up eligibility exists for people who missed prior school programs (use HBV_CATCHUP_MISSED_SCHOOL).
High-risk medical or exposure categories may qualify for publicly funded hepatitis B vaccination (use risk tags from your intake form).

vaccineRules.notes: This rule is intentionally simplified: Manitoba’s HB eligibility includes several cohort/exposure categories. Model those categories as riskTags collected via a questionnaire.

reasons: Use the combination vaccine when the patient meets eligibility for both hepatitis A and hepatitis B (set riskTag HAHB_ELIGIBLE).
Immunocompromised (incl. HIV/transplant) individuals may be eligible for a 3-dose publicly funded HPV series up to age 45.
Certain high-risk groups may qualify for publicly funded HPV vaccination (model as risk tags from intake).
School-based HPV program typically uses a 2-dose series when started before age 15 (set GRADE6_PROGRAM/HPV_SCHOOL_PROGRAM).
Catch-up HPV vaccination may use a 3-dose series when started at age 15+.

vaccineRules.notes: Use gender/birth-cohort filters if you want to mirror Manitoba’s “healthy cohort” wording. For hackathons, using program tags (GRADE6_PROGRAM) + age bands is usually enough.

reasons: IPV is publicly funded for children/youth under 18 who are not fully immunized for polio.
Certain specialist-directed schedules (e.g., oncology/transplant) may qualify for IPV outside routine age bands.
Infants 6–11 months may be eligible for an early MMR dose during outbreaks or before travel (still needs routine doses later).
Routine MMR schedule: dose at 12 months and a second dose at 4–6 years.
Health care workers typically require 2 doses of MMR if not immune/fully documented.
Post-secondary students born before 1970 may be eligible for 1 dose if not immune/fully documented.
Post-secondary students born in/after 1970 may be eligible for 2 doses if not immune/fully documented.
General population born in/after 1985 may need 2 documented MMR doses.
General population born 1970–1984 may be eligible for 1 dose if not immune/fully documented.

vaccineRules.notes: Immunity can also come from lab evidence or past infection; if you collect that, add riskTag HAS_MMR_IMMUNITY to short-circuit eligibility.

reasons: MMRV is publicly funded for children (under 13) when both MMR and varicella protection are needed.

vaccineRules.notes: Implementation tip: count an MMRV dose as both an MMR dose and a Varicella dose.

reasons: Outbreak eligibility: infants 6 weeks to <6 months may receive a 2-dose primary series plus the routine 12-month dose (simplified as 3 doses).
Outbreak eligibility: infants 6 months to <12 months may receive 1 dose now plus the routine 12-month dose (simplified as 2 doses).
Routine program includes a meningococcal C dose at 12 months for eligible birth cohorts.
Catch-up: children who missed the 12-month meningococcal C dose may be eligible (set MENC_MISSED_12M).
School program: Men-C-ACYW offered around Grade 6 (use GRADE6_PROGRAM to confirm).
Catch-up: cohorts who missed earlier school programs may be eligible (set MENC_CATCHUP_MISSED_GRADE4).
High-risk medical conditions may qualify for meningococcal vaccination and periodic boosters (simplified booster interval).

vaccineRules.notes: Men-C programs involve multiple products and age-dependent schedules; this is a simplified, tag-driven model suitable for a hackathon.

reasons: High-risk/outbreak: starting MenB at 2–5 months requires a 3-dose series (simplified).
High-risk/outbreak: starting MenB at 6–11 months requires a 3-dose series (simplified).
High-risk/outbreak: starting MenB at 12–23 months requires a 2-dose series (simplified).
High-risk/outbreak: starting MenB at age 2–25 years requires a 2-dose series (simplified).

vaccineRules.notes: MenB is not routine for everyone; it’s publicly funded for specific high-risk/outbreak categories (collect those categories as riskTags).

reasons: Post-exposure prophylaxis may be offered to close contacts of a confirmed/probable mpox case (set MPOX_POST_EXPOSURE_CLOSE_CONTACT).
Pre-exposure prophylaxis may be offered to specific high-risk groups and some occupational/travel categories (set appropriate MPOX_PREP_* tags).

vaccineRules.notes: Mpox eligibility includes behaviour/occupation/travel details that are not in your base profile—collect them via a short questionnaire and store as riskTags.

reasons: Routine pneumococcal program for children uses a 3-dose conjugate series.
Adults 65+ may be eligible for a single publicly funded Pneu-C-20 dose if they have not received Pneu-P-23 since turning 65.
Adults 18+ with specified high-risk medical conditions may be eligible for a single Pneu-C-20 dose.
Children 2 months to <2 years with high-risk conditions (and some First Nations community programs) may receive a 4-dose Pneu-C-20 series.
Children/youth age 2 to <18 with high-risk medical conditions may be eligible for a single Pneu-C-20 dose.

vaccineRules.notes: Intervals after prior pneumococcal vaccines can matter. Keep it simple by enforcing: at least 56 days after the last pneumococcal conjugate dose and 5 years after any PNEU_P23 dose when applicable.
Manitoba’s current eligibility page mainly references PNEU_P23 as a prior vaccine for timing checks. Treat it as a history-only key unless you add separate eligibility rules.

reasons: Pre-exposure rabies vaccination may be publicly funded for certain occupations at risk of rabies exposure.
Post-exposure rabies prophylaxis is managed urgently by public health (model as RABIES_EXPOSURE).

vaccineRules.notes: Post-exposure management is clinical/urgent. For a hackathon, treat RABIES_EXPOSURE as an external flag set by a clinician/public health workflow.

reasons: RSV vaccine is publicly funded for older adults 75+ (single dose).
Adults 60–74 may be eligible for a publicly funded RSV vaccine if they meet specific high-risk criteria (model as tags).

vaccineRules.notes: RSV eligibility includes care-setting and clinical risk factors; model those as riskTags.

vaccineRules.displayName: RSV prevention for infants (nirsevimab; not a vaccine)

reasons: Infants born between Oct 1, 2025 and Mar 31, 2026 may be eligible for one publicly funded dose of RSV monoclonal antibody (nirsevimab).
Other infants/children may be eligible case-by-case via high-risk programs (set RSV_HIGH_RISK_INFANT_PROGRAM_APPROVED).

vaccineRules.notes: This is a simplified representation of Manitoba’s infant RSV prevention program.

reasons: Dose 1 is eligible only within the early infancy window and for infants born on/after Apr 1, 2021.
Dose 2 is eligible only if it can be completed before 8 months of age.
All Manitobans 6 months+ are eligible for publicly funded seasonal influenza vaccine each season (set INFLUENZA_SEASON_ACTIVE).

vaccineRules.notes: Influenza is seasonal; store a per-season vaccination record (e.g., FLU_2025_2026) or set INFLUENZA_SEASON_ACTIVE and treat doseCount as “this season only”.

reasons: Tdap is recommended during each pregnancy; model trimester timing as additional tags if you want more precision.
People 7+ should receive at least one Tdap dose if they have never had Tdap documented.
A tetanus/diphtheria/pertussis booster is typically due every ~10 years (simplified as Tdap).

vaccineRules.notes: In real practice, Td/Tdap choices can depend on wound management and prior series; this is a simplified “Tdap now if never had it; otherwise every 10 years” model.

reasons: Routine preschool booster around age 4–6 uses Tdap-IPV.
Catch-up schedules may use Tdap-IPV when a polio booster is required (set POLIO_CATCHUP_NEEDS_BOOSTER).

vaccineRules.displayName: Tetanus + Diphtheria (Td) — discontinued for publicly funded programs
vaccineRules.notes: Manitoba’s eligibility page notes Td is discontinued; use Tdap instead.

vaccineRules.displayName: DTaP-IPV — discontinued for publicly funded programs
vaccineRules.notes: Manitoba’s eligibility page notes DTaP-IPV is discontinued; use Tdap-IPV for the preschool booster.

reasons: Some higher-risk patients may receive varicella under specialist direction; model this as a tag.
Routine varicella vaccination is offered to susceptible children (under 13) with 2 doses.
Susceptible people age 13+ may be eligible for 2 varicella doses (contraindications apply).

vaccineRules.notes: Varicella is a live vaccine. In real practice, pregnancy and many immunocompromising conditions are contraindications; keep those as forbidRiskTagsAny unless a specialist-approved path exists.
